title: 113_hr4515
content: The Act titled "Getting into Researching, Learning, & Studying of STEM Act of 2014" or "GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014" provides grants to prepare female students for the 21st century under Title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This includes a program authority outlined in Section 5701. The GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014 provides grants to encourage female students in STEM careers and help them pursue industry-recognized credentials. Grants are awarded in 4-year increments. Eligible schools can apply for these grants. To be eligible for a grant under the GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014, a local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with a program description and details on collaboration between schools to improve science and mathematics education. The GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014 aims to enhance STEM education for female students in K-12 by outlining recruitment processes, instructional activities, and necessary collaborations with institutions. The Secretary considers applications from local educational agencies demonstrating a commitment to program goals. The GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014 requires eligible local educational agencies to use grant funds for activities such as introducing female students to STEM careers, educating parents on STEM opportunities, providing tutoring and mentoring programs, and establishing partnerships. The GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014 mandates local educational agencies to use grant funds for activities like exposing female students to STEM role models, organizing after-school and summer programs to develop their skills and interest in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology, and purchasing educational materials to encourage their engagement in STEM subjects. The GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014 requires educational agencies to provide academic and career counseling, internships, and professional development for teachers to eliminate gender bias and engage female students in STEM subjects. The GIRLS-STEM Act of 2014 mandates educational agencies to offer counseling, internships, and teacher training to address gender bias and involve female students in STEM fields. Local educational agencies receiving grants must enhance instructional strategies in science, math, engineering, and technology, and provide evaluations to the Secretary annually. They are also required to supplement, not supplant, other non-Federal funding for these activities. For this part, an eligible local educational agency is defined as one serving underrepresented or low-income students. Authorization of appropriations for the program "Preparing Females for the 21st Century" is set at $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2015 through 2019.
